12:30 REPORT

Itâ€™s Tuesday. If youâ€™re near the DMV, it may be beautiful and springlike, but do not trust it! In this edition:

  • RFK Jr. advances.
  • Tulsi Gabbard gets a critical â€œyesâ€ vote.
  • Trumpâ€™s government purges
  • Trump and Netanyahu meet.

Â 

Iâ€™mÂ CateÂ MartelÂ with a quick recap of the morning and whatâ€™s coming up. Send tips, feedback & cookie recipes toÂ cmartel@thehill.com.â€¯Someone forward this to you?â€¯Sign up.

ğŸOn Capitol Hill

â€Š

Well, Iâ€™ll be a monkeyâ€™s uncle!:

Â©Â  GIPHY/National Geographic TV

Robert F. Kennedy Jr. successfully made it out of the Senate Finance Committee this morning, eking through in a party-line vote. And Tulsi Gabbardâ€™s chances just increased after she got the support from a key Republican this morning.

Â 

First, Kennedy â€” why this is noteworthy: Just one Republican â€œnoâ€ vote would have tanked his nomination in committee. Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-La.) had serious doubts about Kennedy. Heâ€™s a medical doctor and was visibly agitated over Kennedyâ€™s response to unfounded past claims linking autism to vaccines. Cassidy, who is up for reelection in 2026 in ruby-red Louisiana, ultimately voted â€œyesâ€ to advancing the nomination. Â ğŸ” Read Cassidyâ€™s justification for his vote

Â 

This now sets Kennedy up for a full Senate confirmation vote.

Â 

Next, Gabbard â€” two biggies in one day: The Senate Intelligence Committee will vote at 2 p.m. on Tulsi Gabbardâ€™s nomination to serve as director of national intelligence. Like Kennedy, she cannot afford to lose a single Republican committee vote.

Â 

ğŸš¨ Gabbard just got an important â€˜yesâ€™ in her column: Republican Sen. Todd Young (Ind.), a former Marine who has been on the fence about Gabbard, just announced that he will vote â€œyes.â€ While Gabbardâ€™s refusal to label Edward Snowden (the ex-NSA contractor who leaked classified documents and fled the U.S.) a traitor, kept Young from fully supporting her, he ultimately came around.Â 

Â 

Plus: Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) had been on the fence about Gabbard but announced Monday that she *will* support Trumpâ€™s nominee.

Â 

Keep in mind:Â Beyond the committee vote, there are several GOP senators to watch if Gabbardâ€™s nomination moves to a floor vote, including Sens. Mitch McConnell (Ky.), Lisa Murkowski (Alaska) and John Curtis (Utah).Â 

Â 

Still, four Republican senators in total would need to break ranks in order for the nomination to fail.Â 

Â 

ğŸ—¨ï¸ Follow todayâ€™s live blog

â€Š

â¤ Â HAPPENING ON WEDNESDAY:

The Senate has teed up a final vote on Pam Bondiâ€™s nomination to lead the Justice Department for early Wednesday.

â€Š

â¤ Â TIDBIT:

Trump is inviting all Republican senators and their spouses to a private dinner at Mar-a-Lago on Friday, reports Punchbowl News. ğŸ“¸ The invitation

â€Š

They may need a bigger chopping block:

President Trump is actively trying to dismantle several parts of the federal government.

Â 

First, USAID: His top target has been the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), which facilitates humanitarian aid to developing countries and regions facing conflict. Â 

Whatâ€™s happening at USAID:

  • Secretary of State Marco Rubio has been put in charge of the agency while his team decides its fate.
  • Dozens of senior officials have been furloughed
  • Hundreds of contract employees have been laid off.
  • Employees have been told to stay home.

And now, the Education Department: Trump is reportedly drafting an executive order to slowly dismantle the Education Department, according to The Washington Post. Technically, only Congress can shut down the department (and that would be very unlikely), so the executive order would find ways to eliminate pieces of it. Whatâ€™s happening at the Department of Education:

  • The Trump administration has already placed dozens of department staffers on leave.
  • Several Department of Government Efficiency staffers have access to the internal systems, including personal information for students receiving federal aid.

Plus, heâ€™s purging the DOJ and FBI: The administration has fired dozens of Department of Justice (DOJ) and FBI officials as part of its purge. Whatâ€™s happening there:

  • The five highest career positions at the FBI have been fired, plus the heads of multiple field offices.
  • Those who worked on Trumpâ€™s two criminal prosecutions have been fired â€” and were escorted out of the building.
  • The agents and lawyers who charged the Jan. 6 defendants have been let go.
â€Š

â¤ Â TIDBIT:Â 

Roughly 24,000 federal workers have taken the Trump administrationâ€™s buyout offer so far, reports NOTUSâ€™s Reese Gorman.

Â 

The offer is good until Thursday, but this amounts to about 1 percent of the federal government. The administration was hoping 5-10 percent of workers would accept.

Trade war? Thatâ€™s a March problem:Â 

President Trump averted a trade war that he began, reaching deals with Canada and Mexico to delay the threatened 25 percent tariff against two of the U.S.â€™s biggest trading partners by another month.

Â 

Yes, but: Trumpâ€™s 10 percent tariff on all Chinese goods took effect at midnight.

Â 

What happened?: â€œTrump and his allies claimed victory after Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum agreed to send 10,000 troops to the U.S.-Mexico border in return for a monthlong delay of tariffs and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau promised to name a fentanyl czar and to establish a Canada-U.S. Joint Strike Force to fight organized crime, smuggling and money laundering.â€

Â 

How is Washington feeling about all of this?: â€œBut the sudden halt on major tariffs set to go into effect Tuesday left lawmakers on Capitol Hill with a sense of whiplash after watching financial markets yo-yo in response to the presidentâ€™s rapidly evolving policy pronouncements. A sense of alarm spread among GOP lawmakers Monday morning after the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500 and NASDAQ plunged in premarket trading.â€

Â 

Read Alexander Boltonâ€™s reporting: â€˜Trumpâ€™s tariff threats give Washington whiplashâ€™

Â 

ğŸ™ï¸ Listen to todayâ€™s episode of NYTâ€™s â€˜The Dailyâ€™: â€˜How North America averted a trade war, for nowâ€™

â€Š

â¤ Â READ MORE:

  • The Wall Street Journal: Inside the Chaotic Run-Up to Trumpâ€™s Tariff U-Turn
  • The New York Times: Trump Riles Washington as He Tries to Overthrow the Existing Order
  • The Washington Post: Red states, following Trumpâ€™s lead, pursue sweeping immigration measures
  • Axios: Trumpâ€™s obsession: He canâ€™t quit bashing Biden
  • The Hill: 5 things to know about Trumpâ€™s plan to create a sovereign wealth fund

ğŸÂ Internet Buzz

â€Š

ğŸ² Celebrate: Today is National Homemade Soup Day.

ğŸ¤µ Whoâ€™s headlining the WHCA dinner this year?: Comedian and writer Amber Ruffin is emceeing this yearâ€™s White House Correspondentsâ€™ Association (WHCA) dinner on April 26. She works for CNNâ€™s comedic news show â€œHave I Got News For Youâ€ and is a writer for â€œLate Night with Seth Myers.â€

Â 

ğŸ§³ Just the vacation we all want: North Korea reopened to tourists just in time to celebrate the late leader Kim Jong Ilâ€™s birthday.

ğŸ“† On The Agenda

â€Š

The House and Senate are in. President Trump and Vice President Vance are in Washington. (all times Eastern)

â€Š
  • Noon: Secretary of State Marco Rubio held a joint news conference with Costa Rican President Rodrigo Chaves Robles. ğŸ’» Livestream ğŸ“¹ Watch Rubio land in Costa Rica
  • 2 p.m.: Trump signs executive orders.
  • 4 p.m.: Trump meets with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the Oval Office.
  • 5:10 p.m.: Trump and Netanyahu hold a joint press conference. ğŸ’» Livestream

  • 6:30 p.m.: First and last House votes. ğŸ“† Todayâ€™s agenda

    Just announced â€” Feb. 10: Vance will travel to Europe for his first foreign trip since his inauguration.

ğŸ‘‹ And Finallyâ€¦

â€Š

Letâ€™s end this with some good vibes. We should all learn to share like these adorable buddies.

data.title: White House begins migrant flights to Guantanamo Bay
data.description:
The Trump administration on Tuesday began flying immigrants who entered the country illegally to Guantanamo Bay amid plans to use the facility in Cuba to house thousands of migrants.

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt confirmed that the first flights from the U.S. to Guantanamo Bay carrying â€œillegal migrantsâ€ were underway.

â€œPresident Trump is not messing around, and heâ€™s no longer going to allow America to be a dumping ground for illegal criminals from nations all over this world,â€ Leavitt said on Fox Business Network.

President Trump last week signed a memo directingÂ the Department of Defense and Department of Homeland Security to prepare a 30,000-person migrant facility at GuantÃ¡namo Bay, a facility in Cuba that has been used to house military prisoners, including several involved in the 9/11 attacks.

GuantÃ¡namo Bay is best known as a military base where terror suspects are held. It became infamous for accusations of torture and abuse as the U.S. carried out the war on terrorism. The Biden administration sought toÂ wind down operationsÂ at the facility. There are 15 detainees still there.

â€œDue process will be followed, and having facilities at GuantÃ¡namo Bay will be an asset to us,â€ Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said Sunday on â€œMeet the Press.â€

Noem would not say whether women and children would be kept at Guantanamo Bay.

The Trump administration has aggressively moved to remove individuals who entered the U.S. illegally, setting up agreements with Colombia, Venezuela and El Salvador for those countries to accept deported immigrants.

data.title: Raskin: â€˜Iâ€™m with Steve Bannon and Laura Loomerâ€™ and others saying â€˜Watch Elon Muskâ€™
data.description:
Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-Md.) said Monday that the Trump administration needs to keep a close eye on billionaire Elon Musk, a key ally of President Trump â€” echoing a warning several outspoken far-right advocates have made.

â€œIâ€™m with Steve Bannon and Laura Loomer and the people on the right who are saying, â€˜Watch Elon Musk,â€™ because heâ€™s the guy whoâ€™s trying to centralize all power behind him and he hasnâ€™t been elected to anything,â€ Raskin said in a Monday interview on MSNBC in an interview Monday.

In recent months, Bannon and Loomer have criticized Musk for his support of nonimmigrant H-1B visas, which they argued only help to spur immigration and place a burden on highly-skilled American workers. As a response, Loomer said parts of her accounts on social platform X have been demonetized and unverified.

Amid their argument, Musk has procured access to high level info within the Treasury Department and the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), which he has pushed to shutter, in addition to supporting attempts to dismantle the Education Department.

â€œI mean, Elon Musk has basically tried to take control of the countryâ€™s communications infrastructure, the governmental financial payments infrastructure, the data infrastructure, and heâ€™s got important parts of nodes of the military infrastructure,â€ Raskin told MSNBCâ€™s â€œThe Rachel Maddow Show.â€

â€œSo Iâ€™m looking right through Donald Trump, who no doubt wants to abuse everybodyâ€™s civil rights and civil liberties and centralize all the power in him,â€ he added.

Democrats have pushed back on the Trump administration through legal battles in court, but those efforts may take months or longer to play out.Â 

Sideliners, including former Rep. Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.), have urged the party to do more amid threats to democracy and national stability while Trump has adamantly denied claims that Musk has unclenched access to power.

â€œHeâ€™s got access only to letting people go that he thinks are no good, if we agree with him and itâ€™s only if we agree with him,â€ Trump said Monday from the Oval Office, referring to Musk.

The president added that the Tesla CEO, â€œcanâ€™t do and wonâ€™t do anything without our approval.â€

data.title: Bill Gates: Musk wouldnâ€™t be telling USAID workers to say home if he knew what it does
data.description:
Billionaire Bill Gates said in an interview early Tuesday that Elon Musk â€œwouldnâ€™t be tellingâ€ employees at the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) not to come to work if he â€œreally knewâ€ what it does.

â€œI give billions of dollars to the same thing that USAID does. I go out in the field and study these things. I hire scientists,â€ Gates said on NBCâ€™s â€œTodayâ€ show.

â€œAnd so, you know, I think if he really knew the work there, he wouldnâ€™t be telling 10,000 people not to come and do that work,â€ he added.

Gates lauded USAID, which has administered billions of dollars of humanitarian and development assistance around the world, as critical in funding global health and nutrition efforts. Despite Muskâ€™s threats to fold the agency into the State Department through a Department of Government Efficiency overhaul, the Microsoft founder said he remains â€œhopefulâ€ regarding USAIDâ€™s future.

â€œYou know, I think all Americans can agree that keeping people alive, you know, for very little money, you know, we should be proud of that,â€ Gates said.Â 

â€œIt started back with President Bush. There is some disruption going on now, and I want to, you know, engage positively to get things back on track.â€

USAID employees told The Hill they are â€œterrifiedâ€ of changes to the agency and are awaiting clear communication from the Trump administration.Â  An email reviewed by The Hill said USAIDâ€™s headquarters at the Ronald Reagan building would be closed Monday and instructed employees to work remotely.Â

data.title: Lethal heat waves will triple in size even if climate agreements kept, study finds
data.description:
Heat waves that are impossible to survive without air-conditioning could soon afflict far more of the globe than they do now, a new study has found.

That change could happen even if climate change is kept within the limits of international agreements, according toÂ findingsÂ published on Tuesday in Nature Reviews Earth and Environment.

Heat waves have killed more than 260,000 people since 1990, and a large body of research shows that human burning of fossil fuelsÂ makes these events more common.

The coming rise in temperaturas means an urgent need for hot-weather countries to adapt to prepare for â€œunsurvivable heat thresholds,â€ lead author Tom Matthews, who teaches environmental geography at Kings College of London, said in aÂ statement.

Those are conditions where â€œprolonged outdoor exposure â€“ even for those if in the shade, subject to a strong breeze, and well hydrated â€“ would be expected to cause lethal heatstrokeâ€ even in the young, Matthews said.

Under current levels of warming, such heat events currently afflict about 2 percent of the Earthâ€™s landmass, or about 14 times the size of Texas, the researchers found. For adults over 60, the regions currently at risk for lethal heat waves are ten times higher: 20 percent of the earthâ€™s surface.

But if average temperatures rise to 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) above pre-industrial levels â€” or just another .5 degrees Celsius (0.9 degrees Fahrenheit) of warming â€” then the regions affected by lethal heat waves will spread until they have enclosed a total global area about the same size as the United States as a whole, the study found.Â 

Those impacts will be worst for parts of densely populated equatorial countries in Sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia, where billions of people could be at risk â€” even if planetary heating is kept at bay by significant shifts in how the worldâ€™s nations use energy and limits on the burning of fossil fuels, according to the study.

If those shifts away from burning coal, oil and gas donâ€™t happen, projections suggest that warming could exceed 4 degrees Celsius (7.2 degreesÂ Fahrenheit). In that scenario, the study found, 40 percentÂ  of the planetâ€™s land area could feel the impacts of heat waves that adults canâ€™t survive.

In that scenario, Matthews said, only regions furthest from the equator â€” or at high elevation â€” would be unaffected.Â 

In all cases, he said, â€œas more of the planet experiences outdoor conditions too hot for our physiology, it will be essential that people have reliable access to cooler environments to shelter from the heat.â€

Such protections may require more than simply access to air conditioning. While air conditioning is nearly ubiquitous across the cities of the Southern U.S., these protections are vulnerable to disaster. During post-hurricane blackouts last July, millions of residents of Houston, Texas,Â sweated in the heat and darkÂ for more than a week â€” underscoring the overlapping dangers posed by a heating planet.

data.title: Ocasio-Cortez: Musk â€˜one of the most unintelligent billionaires I have ever metâ€™
data.description:
Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) slammed tech billionaire and â€œDepartment of Government Efficiencyâ€ (DOGE) head Elon Musk as â€œone of the most unintelligent billionaires that I have ever met.â€

In a live video on her Instagram, Ocasio-Cortez weighed in on Muskâ€™s influence over the federal government as DOGE examines and infiltrates various agencies, including the Treasury Department and the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID).

â€œThis dude is probably one of the most unintelligent billionaires I have ever met or seen or witnessed,â€ she said.

Ocasio-Cortez slammed DOGE for not doing â€œtheir homeworkâ€ and putting 19-year-olds in positions of power at the Treasury Department.

â€œThis dude is not smart, and the danger in the lack of intelligence and the lack of expertise that Elon has, I mean, this guy is one of the most morally vacant, but also just least knowledgeable about these systems that we know of,â€ she continued.

The New York Democrat argued that there will be a point, or â€œa buttonâ€ that will be hit when things â€œgo sideways.â€

Over the last several days, thereâ€™s been concern as Musk and DOGE gained access to the Treasury Departmentâ€™s federal payment system. Despite some employees pushing back, they were given access to the departmentâ€™s system that controls $6 trillion annually to distribute federal funds.

It controls funding for Social Security and Medicare, salaries for federal workers, payments to government contractors and grant recipients, and tax refunds.

DOGE officials have defended their actions by saying they are making sure government spending aligns with the Trump administrationâ€™s agenda, but Democrats, like Ocasio-Cortez, are sounding the alarm that confidential and sensitive information could have been compromised.

Officials at DOGE also essentially shut down USAID and attempted to put the international aid agency under the State Department.

The Hill has reached out to a contact at DOGE for comment.

data.title: At least 20K have accepted Trumpâ€™s government buyout offer
data.description:
At least 20,000 federal employees have accepted what amounts to a buyout from the Trump administration, a source confirmed to The Hill on Tuesday.

Employees still have until Feb. 6 to accept the offer to resign and get paid through September, and the source told The Hill the number of resignations are expected to increase sharply ahead of the deadline at the end of the week.

Axios first reported on the 20,000 figure, which amounts to roughly 1 percent of the federal workforce.

The Trump administration last monthÂ offered 2 million federal employees the opportunity to resign ahead of return to office requirements as part of an effort to shrink the workforce.Â 

A union representing federal employees has cautioned workers against accepting the offer, andÂ lawmakersÂ representing federal workers in the Washington, D.C., area railed against the deal.

Elon Musk, a top Trump ally who has a hand in the effort, said the offer would give employees time to â€œtake the vacation you always wanted, or just watch movies and chill.â€Â 

But theÂ offerâ€™s vague languageÂ is igniting skepticism and calls for workers to reject the deal, while raising questions about whether the government has the legal authority to do it.

data.title: Jon Stewart urges Democrats to stop â€˜trotting Schumer outâ€™ to respond to Trump
data.description:
Jon Stewart says Chuck Schumer isnâ€™t the most effective messenger in combating President Trumpâ€™s rhetoric, urging Democrats to quit frequently turning to the Senate minority leader.

â€œDemocrats, can you please stop fâ€”ing trotting Schumer out there every time Trump traverses into the unreal?â€Â Stewart saidÂ Monday while hosting Comedy Centralâ€™s â€œThe Daily Show.â€

â€œHeâ€™s not good at this,â€ Stewart said, after playing a clip of the New York Democrat reacting toÂ weighty tariffsÂ on Canada, Mexico and China that Trump had announced over the weekend.

On Monday,Â Trump pausedÂ the threat of 25 percent tariffs against Canada and Mexico for one month.

â€œItâ€™s going to affect beer, most of it â€” Corona here â€” comes from Mexico. Itâ€™s going to affect your guac. Because what is guacamole made of? Avocados,â€ Schumer said on Sunday while railing against the tariffs and their potential impact on Americansâ€™ wallets.Â 

â€œYour response to the trade war is to fâ€”ing tell us guacamole is made of avocados?â€ Stewart exclaimed.

â€œWhat is the decision-making process here?â€ he asked Democrats.

Imagining a meeting among Democratic operatives, Stewart said, â€œHey, who should we get out there to effectively battle one of the most savvy presidential media manipulators in history? How about Schumer? Heâ€™s uninteresting, but at least heâ€™s monotone.â€

Stewart also cracked of the 74-year-old lawmaker, â€œAnd Chuck, before you go out there, you look too young. Put on these readers and lower them on your nose.â€

A spokesman for Schumer didnâ€™t immediately return ITKâ€™s request for comment.

â€œHonestly, listening to Chuck Schumer speak on almost any topic,â€ Stewart told his audience, â€œmakes me want to bomb Canada.â€

data.title: Mystery OPM server that aided buyout offers prompts House Democrat probe
data.description:
House Oversight Democrats are demanding answers about the installation of a â€œserver of unknown nature and originâ€ at the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) that aided the agency in sending buyout offers to federal employees.

The letter asks for a list of employees that installed the equipment, the authority under which they were hired, and whether they faced background investigations â€“ a nod to a Reddit post saying employees outside OPM installed the server.

The installation of the server appears to have been a stepping stone in OPMâ€™s work to assemble a list of federal employee emails ahead of offering theÂ â€œFork in the Roadâ€ buyout packageÂ to nearly all employees â€“ a brainchild of Elon Musk.

But in doing so, OPM may have violated laws dictating how the agency must plan for using databases with personally identifiable information.

â€œAt best, the Trump Administrationâ€™s actions at OPM to date demonstrate gross negligence, severe incompetence, and a chaotic disregard for the security of our government data and the countless services it enables our agencies to provide to the public,â€ said the letter from Rep. Gerry Connolly (D-Va.), the committeeâ€™s top Democrat, and Rep. Shantel Brown (D-Ohio.).

â€œAt worst, we fear that Trump Administration officials know full well that their actions threaten to break our government and put our citizens at risk of foreign adversaries like China and Russia gaining access to our sensitive data.â€

OPM isÂ already facing a suitÂ under the E-Government Act of 2002, which requires a Privacy Impact Assessment before pushing ahead with creation of databases that store personally identifiable information.

The letter also seeks details about how OPM was able to assemble a list of employees â€“ something that appears to be done from cobbling together existing email lists and datasets. Email metadata reviewed by The Hill show multiple email subdomains and servers affiliated with the process.

Most messages to staff are handled through each agency and the government did not previously have the capability to send such far-reaching emails.

Democrats argue that â€œacquiring such a capability securely and in compliance with federal cybersecurity, privacy, and procurement laws would likely not have been possible in such a short timeframe.â€

Their concerns are not hypothetical.

Employees at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration alreadyÂ received emailsÂ fromÂ outside the organization.Â Â 

â€œThe lack of security and oversight associated with the new email system and data management practices threatens to expose federal workers to personalized social engineering or â€˜spear phishingâ€™ attacks to gain access to government systems,â€ the two lawmakers wrote.

OPM did not immediately respond to request for comment.

The letter comes as lawmakers have sounded the alarm over other efforts from those associated with the Department of Government Efficiency to access government databases, including at the Treasury Department.

data.title: China to investigate Google amid tensions with US
data.description:
China said Tuesday that it is investigating Google for potential antitrust violations after the Trump administration levied new tariffs on Beijing.Â 

The Chinese State Administration for Market Regulation announced in a press release that it is probing the tech giant over suspicions it violated the countryâ€™s anti-monopoly laws. Â 

The investigation is the latest apparent retaliation to President Trumpâ€™s 10 percent tariffs on China. In addition to Beijing, the president also imposed 25 percent tariffs on Canada and Mexico over the weekend, although both countries reached agreements for a 30-day pause. Â 

China responded Monday with a 15 percent tariff on liquefiedÂ natural gas and coal and a 10 percent tariff on crude oil, pickup trucks, agricultural machinery and large-displacement cars.Â Â 

It also announced plans to impose export controls on several critical elements, including tellurium, bismuth, tungsten, indium and molybdenum.Â  Â 

â€œThe USâ€™s unilateral imposition of tariffs seriously violates the rules of the World Trade Organization,â€ Chinaâ€™s State Council Tariff Commission said. â€œIt is not only unhelpful in solving its own problems but also undermines the normal economic and trade cooperation between China and the US.â€Â  Â 

The tech industry is likely to be a key factor in the U.S.-China trade war. The U.S. had already placed strict export controls on advanced chips under the Biden administrationÂ in an effort to stymie Beijingâ€™s artificial intelligence (AI) development. Â 

The recent emergence of Chinese AI startup DeepSeek has raised questions about the effectiveness of export controls and American firmsâ€™ approach to developing AI.Â 

DeepSeek claims its new R1 model can perform on par with OpenAI and was developed with just a couple thousand reduced-capacity chips for a final price tag of $5.6 million. Â 

This threatened to upend the current consensus on AI development, which assumed that new models would require vast investment in AI infrastructure. American AI firms, like OpenAI, Meta and Microsoft, have committed billions of dollars to securing chips and building out data centers.

After DeepSeek surged to the top of the Apple App Store last week, investors panicked, triggering a significant sell-off in the tech sector that saw chipmaker Nvidia lose $600 billion in a single day. Â 

However, some have cast doubt on DeepSeekâ€™s claims about its R1 model, including the total cost of training and whether more advanced chips were used.Â U.S. officials are reportedly investigating whether DeepSeek managed to circumvent American export controls to obtain advanced chips through Singapore, according to Bloomberg.
